etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Quarterly Journal of the Chemical Society. From but- + -ene

definitions: Each of four isomeric gaseous alkenes, having the general formula C₄ H₈, which are used as reagents in chemical synthesis, especially in the production of polymers; also called butylene.

notes.text: The isomers of butene are: "1-butene" or "but-1-ene" (CH₂=CHCH₂CH₃); "2-butene" or "but-2-ene" (cis and trans isomers) (CH₃CH=CHCH₃); and "iso-butene" (2-methyl-prop-1-ene) (CH₃CH₂CH=CH₂).
